Award.AwardTitle: Enhance Science Education at Claflin University Via Targeted Infusion of Chemical Instrumentation in Chemistry Laboratory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The targeted infusion project of Claflin University has as its goal to enhance the scientific teaching and research infrastructure in the Department of Chemistry at Claflin University. This will be achieved with the upgrade and redesign of several chemistry laboratories and incorporation of summer and academic year undergraduate internships. As a result, Claflin University is expected to improve student retention in several gatekeeping chemistry courses, enhance the critical thinking skills of chemistry students and increase the overall retention rate of chemistry and biochemistry majors by 15%. Ultimately, the activities proposed for Claflin University will not only expose students to cutting edge research in the chemical sciences, but will also improve their capacities to compete for highly coveted undergraduate research opportunities. As such, it is expected that a significant percentage of Claflin students will, subsequently, matriculate into STEM graduate degree programs, thereby contributing to the diversification of the US STEM workforce.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funds from the National Science Foundation were used to procure three portable Raman Spectrometers and an Isothermal Calorimeter (ITC). These new analytical instruments are used for both teaching and research related activities and they are available for use to all STEM students and faculty at Claflin University. In addition funds from this grant were used to provide hands on research experience to undergraduate students and professional development opportunities to chemistry faculty. Results from this project were presented at regional American Chemical Society meetings by undergraduate student researchers. 

 Performance Outcomes: 

1. Enrollment in the Biochemistry major increased by 3.33% and Chemistry major enrollment increased by 16.66% between 2010-11 and 2012-13.

2. Biochemistry graduates increased by 6 between 2010-11 and 2012-13. Chemistry graduates increased by 2 between 2010-11 and 2011-12, but dropped to 0 in 2012-13.

3. The number of published student research articles increased by 2 in year 1 of the project, and by 4 in year 2 of the project, for an overall increase of 6 to date.

4. The following labs were added to teaching curriculum:  Physical Chemistry II using the Portable Raman Analyzer; and Physical Chemistry I and Biochemistry I using the ITC.

5.  As an extension to this project PIs will introduce SERS (Surface enhanced Raman Spectroscopy) techniques to our Junior and Senior students.  This will be a focus of a future proposal to the South Carolina Space Grant Consortium (SCSGC).
